caption_original: Canada's largest national park, Wood Buffalo National Park, boasts the largest beaver dam in THE WORLD! Average beaver dams in Canada are 10 to 100 metres long. This one spans about 850 metres, an animal-made structure so large it is visible from space! http://ow.ly/Rbhp301W6vo #WildlifeWednesday

caption_original:
#DidYouKnow that Glacier National Park’s Mount Macdonald, popular with hikers, skiers and climbers, was named in honour of Sir John A. Macdonald?

Visit the online exhibit 'Macdonald and Cartier: Architects of Modern Canada' to learn more about this Father of Confederation, and Canada's first Prime Minister. http://ow.ly/QNVy301UPDB #HistoryWeek2016  
Mount Revelstoke and Glacier national parks

©Parks Canada / J. Bolingbroke

caption_original: Gros Morne National Park wasn’t named a UNESCO World Heritage site just for its breathtaking beauty. What makes this site remarkable is its geology! This national park is considered a textbook illustration of plate tectonics. Be sure to visit the Gros Morne Discovery Centre to learn why this place rocks! http://ow.ly/caru302eXGf
caption_cleaned: Gros Morne National Park wasn’t named a UNESCO World Heritage site just for its breathtaking beauty. What makes this site remarkable is its geology! This national park is considered a textbook illustration of plate tectonics. Be sure to visit the Gros Morne Discovery Centre to learn why this place rocks!

caption_original:
Name that park... reserve! (Hint, hint). #TriviaTuesday

ANSWER: it's the Mingan Archipelago National Park Reserve! Find the scattering of spectacular limestone islands, islets and reefs along the North Shore of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Ideal for any wildlife lover, see seabirds, seals, dolphins and whales, and hundreds of species of rare plants! http://ow.ly/pVLH302CZzH

caption_original:
Did you know today is #WorldJumpDay?
Created in 2006, it was claimed that if 600 million people from the western hemisphere jumped simultaneously, the Earth would move out of its orbit, into one that would not cause global warming. The story was later revealed to be a hoax. But it’s still fun, so jump! 

Photo taken in Georgian Bay Islands National Park.

caption_original:
From coast to coast to coast, you can find #UNESCO #WorldHeritage sites all across Canada! 
In 1978, Nahanni National Park Reserve became one of the first sites in the world to be inscribed on the World Heritage List. If you’re looking for a unique wilderness experience, this site isn’t one to miss. Learn more about what you can do at Nahanni NPR on our website: http://ow.ly/5b16301NrMy #HistoryWeek2016
